questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents wanted a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. According to the mother, delivery was fast and without complications. He is being exclusively breastfed. He appears healthy. He is at 35th percentile for length and at 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by hypocalcemia, which can result from maternal hypocalcemia or diabetes, preterm birth, newborn sepsis, asphyxia, or vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D deficiency is a concern in exclusively breastfed infants who do not receive vitamin D prophylaxis. However, only a prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency would result in hypocalcemia, and this condition is therefore unlikely in a 2-week-old patient. Furthermore, breast milk supplies the infant with abundant calcium, which makes hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Newborns have an increased risk of hemorrhage resulting from low vitamin K values, due to the lack of vitamin K-producing gut flora, limited liver capacity, and poor placental transfer of vitamin K. Breast milk contains very low amounts of vitamin K, so the risk of bleeding does not decrease with breastfeeding. All newborns typically receive an intramuscular vitamin K shot at birth to mitigate this risk. Because this child was delivered at home without any medical intervention, it is very likely that he did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis and is consequently at increased risk of bleeding, including potentially severe brain hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of gastroenteritis. Breast milk contains antibodies and is therefore an important source of protection against numerous infectious diseases. The most abundant antibody found in breast milk is IgA, an integral part of mucosal immunity, which also helps to protect the gastrointestinal mucosa of the infant against gastroenteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of childhood cancers, including leukemias and lymphomas.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is primarily a concern in preterm infants because of their lower stores of iron, although it can also be caused by blood loss during or after birth. However, this newborn was born at term and the delivery did not involve any complications. Breastfed infants are also at risk of IDA because breast milk contains only limited amounts of iron. To prevent IDA in breastfed infants, they should receive an additional iron source starting by 4 months of age in full-term infants and by 2 weeks of age in premature infants. Although this infant is being exclusively breastfed, he is not at increased risk of IDA at this time, as most full-term newborns have sufficient iron stores for up to 4 months.

F) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of both type 1 diabetes mellitus and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

G) INCORRECT:

Scurvy is the clinical manifestation of vitamin C deficiency and is an extremely rare disease in high-income countries. Symptoms include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, corkscrew hair on the body, and generalized weakness and fatigue. Because this newborn is being breastfed and breast milk contains sufficient vitamin C, he does not have an increased risk of scurvy.

H) INCORRECT:

Subacute combined degeneration is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and can lead to severe neural tube defects and developmental disability. Unless the mother already had a deficiency during pregnancy or has a lack of vitamin B12 now, her breast milk should supply enough vitamin B12 to the child.

I) INCORRECT:

Intussusception is generally an idiopathic condition, but is often associated with a triggering viral gastrointestinal infection or less often with lead points. Since this infant is currently being breastfed, he has a decreased risk of gastrointestinal infections, which thereby also decreases his chances of developing intussusception
questions.hint: Natural childbirth is childbirth without routine medical intervention. This patient most likely did not receive the standard postpartum care.

questions.text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is present in breast milk following environmental exposure. Most newborns have already accumulated measurable levels at birth. In regions where the drinking water is not fluoridated, the current recommendation is to administer fluoride to children but not before the age of 6 months due to the risk of fluorosis. Using fluoride to support dental hygiene protects against dental caries, which is not a life-threatening condition.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.
questions.hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old, full-term female infant is brought to the emergency department with bruising and bloody stools. She was born at home by vaginal delivery at 38 weeks and 3 days’ gestation. The pregnancy was uncomplicated with prenatal care from 14 weeks on, and maternal serologies were negative. The mother takes no medications and is breastfeeding exclusively.
The child is alert and vigorous, but bruising is evident bilaterally on her upper and lower extremities. Blood is oozing from the umbilical site, and there is blood-streaked stool in her diaper.
Which laboratory findings would be most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Low platelet count, prolonged prothrombin time, prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
Normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time
Low platelet count, normal prothrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time
Normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
Normal platelet count, prolonged prothrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation appear ill and have both a prolonged prothrombin time and a prolonged aPTT. In addition, their platelet counts and fibrinogen levels are diminished, related to increased fibrin formation and consumption of platelets and coagulation factors.

B) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia and von Willebrand disease are disorders of platelet aggregation. Platelet count, prothrombin time, aPTT, and fibrinogen level are all normal in these disorders.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of thrombocytopenia, a normal prothrombin time, and normal aPTT could have a variety of causes. When this constellation of findings is seen during the first 72 hours of life, it is most likely due to complications of pregnancy, delivery, or antibody-mediated destruction (asphyxia, placental insufficiency, neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia). When the same constellation of findings is seen after the first 72 hours, it is more likely due to postnatal conditions (e.g., sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis), all of which can be more common in premature infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia A is a disorder related to factor VIII deficiency. Affected patients have a normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, and prolonged aPTT.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has physical signs and symptoms of vitamin K-deficient bleeding (VKDB). Classic VKDB develops during the first 2 to 7 days of life and is characterized by nasal, skin, gastrointestinal tract, umbilical, and circumcision-site bleeding. Intracranial hemorrhage is rare.

Laboratory evaluation for VKDB typically reveals a normal or elevated platelet count, a prolonged prothrombin time, and a normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT); in patients with severe deficiency, aPTT may be prolonged as well. Early-onset VKDB may occur in the first day of life and is related to maternal antiepileptic medications that block the action of vitamin K.

Inadequate breast-milk intake is the most important risk factor for classic VKDB in a newborn who is being breastfed exclusively. Breast milk has lower levels of vitamin K than fortified formulas do, and in the first few days of life, most breastfed infants get only small volumes of milk.

To prevent VKDB, a single dose of intramuscular vitamin K (0.5–1.0 mg) should be administered to all infants at birth. Term infants typically receive a 1-mg dose. In some countries, oral vitamin K regimens have been used; however, there is limited evidence to support this approach, and in the United States, intramuscular dosing is the only recommended way to administer vitamin K prophylaxis to newborns. Infants born at home are less likely to have received vitamin K prophylaxis.

Other Considerations in This Case

Hemophilia A is a disorder related to factor VIII deficiency. Affected patients have a normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, and prolonged aPTT.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia and von Willebrand disease are disorders of platelet aggregation. Platelet count, prothrombin time, aPTT, and fibrinogen level are all normal in these disorders.

Patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation appear ill and have both a prolonged prothrombin time and a prolonged aPTT. In addition, their platelet counts and fibrinogen levels are diminished, related to increased fibrin formation and consumption of platelets and coagulation factors.

The combination of thrombocytopenia, a normal prothrombin time, and normal aPTT could have a variety of causes. When this constellation of findings is seen during the first 72 hours of life, it is most likely due to complications of pregnancy, delivery, or antibody-mediated destruction (asphyxia, placental insufficiency, neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia). When the same constellation of findings is seen after the first 72 hours, it is more likely due to postnatal conditions (e.g., sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis), all of which can be more common in premature infants.

In a full-term infant born at home to a mother without a history of thrombocytopenia, all of these diagnoses are less likely than VKDB.

Key learning point: Bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract, umbilicus, skin, nose, or circumcision site in the first week of life in an otherwise healthy newborn should prompt evaluation for vitamin K-deficient bleeding.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old newborn is brought to the clinic with prolonged bleeding from the circumcision site and several bruises on the thighs. The infant was delivered at home after a pregnancy with minimal prenatal care. The parents report no vaccinations or injections given after birth. Physical examination shows normal vital signs. There is no evidence of infection or inherited coagulopathy in the family history (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Prothrombin time
25 sec
10 - 13 sec


APTT
70 sec
30 - 40 sec


Platelet count
250 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease can cause mucocutaneous bleeding and increased APTT due to reduced factor VIII activity, but it does not typically prolong PT. The infant's prolonged PT and APTT with normal platelet count suggest a deficiency in vitamin K-dependent factors. The lack of family history and absence of prophylactic vitamin K administration further support this over an inherited disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia A, a deficiency of Factor VIII, affects the intrinsic pathway, causing isolated prolongation of APTT while PT remains normal. The significant prolongation of both PT and APTT in this infant suggests a broader coagulation factor deficiency. Additionally, Hemophilia A is X-linked and often has a family history of bleeding disorders, which is absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis can cause coagulation abnormalities, including disseminated intravascular coagulation, leading to prolonged clotting times. However, it usually presents with additional signs like thrombocytopenia and systemic infection symptoms, which are absent here. The stable vital signs and lack of infection indicators suggest an alternative cause, such as vitamin K deficiency.

D) CORRECT:

Vitamin K is crucial for the gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, enabling their function in the coagulation cascade. Newborns, especially those not receiving prophylactic vitamin K, often have insufficient levels, leading to impaired clotting factor activity. This results in prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), as both the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways are affected. The clinical presentation of bleeding from a circumcision site and bruising aligns with vitamin K deficiency bleeding, common in newborns with minimal prenatal care and no vitamin K administration.

Key learning point: Vitamin K deficiency in newborns can lead to significant bleeding, known as vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB), and is preventable with prophylactic vitamin K administration at birth.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the Pediatrician by his mother due to increased oozing from the circumcision site and small drops of blood in the diaper. The mother was on phenobarbital during pregnancy for a seizure disorder. The baby did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis at birth. On examination, the infant appears mildly jaundiced but is otherwise stable (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
160 g/L
165 - 195 g/L


Platelet count
200 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Prothrombin time
30 sec
10 - 13 sec


APTT
45 sec
30 - 40 sec



What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibronectin, but not vitamin K–dependent factors II, VII, IX, and X. The prolonged prothrombin time suggests a deficiency in these factors, not a fibrinogen deficiency. Cryoprecipitate is not effective for correcting vitamin K deficiency.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin K is crucial for the gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, which are essential for effective coagulation. This newborn, who did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis and whose mother used phenobarbital during pregnancy, is at risk for vitamin K deficiency. Phenobarbital induces cytochrome P450 enzymes, further depleting vitamin K levels. The prolonged prothrombin time and mildly increased activated partial thromboplastin time indicate a deficiency in vitamin K–dependent factors. Intravenous vitamin K₁ rapidly corrects this deficiency, restoring normal coagulation and reducing bleeding risk.

Key learning point: Newborns are at risk for vitamin K deficiency bleeding, especially if they do not receive prophylactic vitamin K at birth, and maternal use of enzyme-inducing drugs like phenobarbital can exacerbate this risk. Parenteral vitamin K1 is the appropriate treatment for vitamin K deficiency bleeding in infants.

C) INCORRECT:

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) provides clotting factors and can temporarily correct coagulopathy. However, the underlying issue is vitamin K deficiency due to lack of prophylaxis and maternal phenobarbital use. FFP does not address the need for vitamin K to enable the liver to produce functional clotting factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Platelet transfusion is indicated for thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction. This newborn has a normal platelet count, and the bleeding is due to a deficiency in vitamin K–dependent clotting factors, not platelet issues. Platelet transfusion would not correct the coagulopathy.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-week-old male newborn brought to your clinic by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents preferred a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. The mother reports that the delivery was fast and without complications. The infant is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 35th percentile for length and the 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination is normal. Which one of the following complications is this patient at increased risk for at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is primarily a concern in preterm infants because of their lower stores of iron, although it can also be caused by blood loss during or after birth. However, this newborn was born at term and the delivery did not involve any complications. Breastfed infants are also at risk of IDA because breast milk contains only limited amounts of iron. To prevent IDA in breastfed infants, they should receive an additional iron source starting by 4 months of age in full-term infants and by 2 weeks of age in premature infants. Although this infant is being exclusively breastfed, he is not at increased risk of IDA at this time, as most full-term newborns have sufficient iron stores for up to 4 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by hypocalcemia, which can result from maternal hypocalcemia or diabetes, preterm birth, newborn sepsis, asphyxia, or vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D deficiency is a concern in exclusively breastfed infants who do not receive vitamin D prophylaxis. However, only a prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency would result in hypocalcemia, and this condition is therefore unlikely in a 2-week-old patient. Furthermore, breast milk supplies the infant with abundant calcium, which makes hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of gastroenteritis. Breast milk contains antibodies and is therefore an important source of protection against numerous infectious diseases. The most abundant antibody found in breast milk is IgA, an integral part of mucosal immunity, which also helps to protect the gastrointestinal mucosa of the infant against gastroenteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Scurvy is the clinical manifestation of vitamin C deficiency and is an extremely rare disease in high-income countries. Symptoms include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, corkscrew hair on the body, and generalized weakness and fatigue. Because this newborn is being breastfed and breast milk contains sufficient vitamin C, he does not have an increased risk of scurvy.

E) CORRECT:

Newborns have an increased risk of hemorrhage resulting from low vitamin K values, due to the lack of vitamin K-producing gut flora, limited liver capacity, and poor placental transfer of vitamin K. Breast milk contains very low amounts of vitamin K, so the risk of bleeding does not decrease with breastfeeding. All newborns typically receive an intramuscular vitamin K shot at birth to mitigate this risk. Because this child was delivered at home without any medical intervention, it is very likely that he did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis and is consequently at increased risk of bleeding, including potentially severe brain hemorrhage.

Key learning point: Newborns who do not receive vitamin K prophylaxis at birth are at increased risk for life-threatening hemorrhagic disease due to low vitamin K stores and immature gut flora.
questions.hint: Natural childbirth is childbirth without routine medical intervention. This patient most likely did not receive the standard postpartum care.

questions.text: You have just delivered a male newborn weighing 2710 g at 38 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which one of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Key learning point: All newborns should receive vitamin K supplementation at birth to prevent potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease due to low stores and immature gut flora.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

E) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin that crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation for the infant unnecessary.

To prevent neural tube defects and support maternal nutrient needs, folic acid supplementation in individuals planning pregnancy should start at least 3 months before conception and continue throughout pregnancy. After birth, breastfeeding individuals should keep taking a daily multivitamin with folic acid to meet increased nutritional demands and ensure adequate folate levels in breast milk. Therefore, folic acid supplementation is indicated for the mother, not the child.
questions.hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.
